div.head: To the Religious, and well affected Reader.
div.p:
SEeing the World, at this day, so generally transported, with such dangerous, and strange Doctrines; and that all men (almost) hunting after nouelties, doe so eagerly desire that which is pestilent and noysome; in the meane while loathing and reiecting, that which is wholsome and good. It therefore beseemeth all men, (that render the glory of God) but specially
the Ministers of his word, diligently to shew to the people, the true difference betweene verum, and apparens bonum, that is, between • that which is good indeed, and that which seemeth to be so▪ especially in all great and fundamentall poynts of Saluation. To which purpose, I haue diuulged this little Treatise, which in it owne particular, shall (I doubt not) but performe this Office, to which end it is sent: and be as a defensatiue in health against the day of sicknesse, and as a preseruatiue in life, against the day of death. Wherin I soare not with the towring Eagle, into the clouds, neither deale I with Questions of difficulty, (which respect the learned and great wits; let such as list climbe into the third Heauen, and shew from thence high misteries, and vnheard of Reuelations) but casting my selfe vpon the ground, with all humility, I study to informe the meanest of
Gods children (after a plaine and easie manner) in those things, which necessarily appertaine to their eternall happinesse. And amongst the many behoofefull points of Christian Religion, I find none at this day, more necessary to bee taught and embraced, then this of Faith and true Repentance; seeing that fancy is generally reputed Faith, and conceit Conscience, and that Hypocrisie walketh in equall compare with Piety. I had no purpose at the first preaching heereof, to haue committed the same to Print, neither did I euer value it worth the Presse or publike view: only contenting my selfe with the discharge of my duty, and edification of my priuate flocke. But being ouer-ruled heerein, by the importunate intreaty of some of my hearers, and louing friends, I could not denie their request, seeing it intended the publike good. Vse it therefore Godly Reader, and meditate therein for
thy comfort: If thou reapest any profit thereby, giue God the praise, and thou hast sufficiently rewarded my paines. Farewell.

closer.dateline: From my Parsonage house, of S. Peters in Sandwich in Kent, this 3. of Ian. 1617.
closer.signed: Thy vnfaigned Louer in Christ Iesus. HARIM WHITE.
